awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Efficient Relaying and Scheduling for Half-Duplex Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Wireless technology is currently experiencing a transformative revolution fueled mainly by the staggering amount of data traffic and massive number of critical services (e.g., healthcare and education) offered over the wireless medium. A central role in this wireless revolution is played by relaying technologies, whereby data is transferred from a sender to a receiver by having information hop through a pool of relays (i.e., intermediate nodes). Relaying is foreseen to be a key component for enabling the evolving 5G architecture, and supporting next generation Internet of Things networks. This project seeks to develop a comprehensive analysis of several theoretical and practical aspects of wireless relay networks. The research and its outcomes will be integrated into education, and will promote undergraduate and graduate research.

This project focuses on half-duplex mode of operation at the relays whereby each relay uses different time slots/frequency bands for transmission and reception. The proposed research seeks to derive theoretical foundations that shed light on how to operate these relay networks in a provably (information-theoretic) close-to-optimal, yet simple way, and to develop low-complexity algorithms for efficiently achieving the theoretical limits. Special emphasis will be put on devising solutions to schedule the relays for reception/transmission in a simple and efficient way. This will require that several challenges be overcome, including achieving high performance in computationally-constrained networks, and providing robustness against channel variations. Our ultimate goal is to identify solutions that can be implemented in a distributive fashion across the relay nodes, and that require a minimum communication overhead for exchanging the channel state information.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: In this research project, we developed efficient, near-optimal transmission techniques for wireless half-duplex relay networks. Specifically, we first identified the fundamental information-theoretic limits of these networks, and then designed low-complexity algorithms and protocols to achieve these limits as closely as possible.

Intellectual Merit: During the course of this project, there were many new scientific results that were discovered and published, with technical details in the corresponding publications and summarized in annual reports of the project. In particular, the main outcomes of the project included the design of efficient strategies that: (1) schedule the relays for reception and transmission in the simplest way, (2) deliver high performance in complexity-constrained networks, (3) are robust to channel variations, and (4) can be implemented distributively across the nodes with minimal channel state information. This research project has also investigated an interconnection between communication and computing over a wireless relay network. More specifically, a distributed computing scenario in which some of the worker machines are attacked (i.e., the result of their computations is maliciously perturbed) was considered. Leveraging group testing techniques, novel sparse parity-check codes were constructed and used to identify the unreliable workers and to correctly reconstruct the result of the computing task.

Scientific Impact: Our work has made significant contributions to the design of efficient, simple and high-rate performing relaying and scheduling schemes that can be implemented in commercially deployed wireless networks. The project has led to 2 published and 1 under review journal publications, and 7 conference publications, in venues such as IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Information Theory, IEEE Transactions on Information Theory, IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications, IEEE ISIT, and IEEE ITW. The work was also disseminated through several talks by the PIs and students supported by this grant.

Broader Impact: Half-duplex relaying is foreseen to play a key role in the next generation technology, which has the ambitious goal of ensuring ubiquitous communication anytime and anywhere. Relaying indeed represents a vital part of this paradigm, promising performance enhancement of several technology components of the evolving wireless architecture, such as device-to-device communication, mmWave communication, vehicular communication, and unmanned aerial vehicles communication. Despite the larger gains promised by the full-duplex technology compared to half-duplex, commercially deployed wireless networks operate in half-duplex. This stems from several practical restrictions that arise when a node operates in full-duplex, such as proper cancellation of the self-interference. Given this, it is expected that half-duplex will still represent a key technology for next generation wireless networks. Two Ph.D. students have worked on parts of this project, and ideas from this project have also been integrated into course projects.
